title: Disconnection & Reconnection
description: Learn how you handle emotional distance and find your way back.

questions.text: How do I behave when I'm feeling disconnected from you?
choices: I reach out and communicate about it
I wait for you to notice and reach out
I become more attentive or affectionate
I pull back to protect myself

therapeutic.rationale: Disconnection responses reveal attachment coping. Reach-outers have secure communication skills; waiters have passive hope or fear of rejection; attentive-increasers try to earn connection back; pull-backers protect against further hurt. How you respond to disconnection determines whether it heals or deepens.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different disconnection responses can widen the gap. The pull-backer's protection looks like rejection to the attentive-increaser; the waiter's patience looks like indifference to the reach-outer. Name your pattern.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared disconnection responses create predictable patterns. Two pull-backers may drift apart; two reach-outers will pursue each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel disconnected, what do you do? Does your response bring you closer or create more distance?

questions.text: What helps me reconnect with you after feeling distant?

therapeutic.rationale: Reconnection paths align with attachment soothing and love languages. Deep-talkers need verbal processing; physical-intimacy seekers need bodily connection; quality-time needers need presence; verbal-love hearers need explicit expression. Knowing your partner's reconnection path helps you bridge distance effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different reconnection paths can miss. The deep-talker may feel the physical-seeker is avoiding; the physical-seeker may feel the deep-talker is intellectualizing. Use your partner's path, not yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reconnection paths make bridging natural. You'll instinctively offer what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: After feeling distant, what brings you back together? What reconnection attempts have failed? What works best?

questions.text: When I feel you pulling away, I tend to:
choices: Match your distance to feel safe

therapeutic.rationale: Response to partner's withdrawal defines relationship dynamics. Direct-askers have secure communication; space-givers show trust or avoidance; pursuers have anxious activation; distance-matchers protect through mirroring. The pursue-withdraw cycle is one of the most common relationship patterns.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different withdrawal responses create cycles. The pursuer's attempts feel smothering to the withdrawer; the withdrawer's distance feels abandoning to the pursuer. Both are trying to feel safe.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared withdrawal responses need awareness. Two pursuers can escalate; two distance-matchers can drift apart without either bridging.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When your partner seems distant, what do you do? Does your response help or make things worse? What would be more effective?

questions.text: What pattern do I fall into during relationship stress?
choices: Staying steady while working through it

therapeutic.rationale: Stress patterns reveal activated attachment styles. Anxious-seekers have preoccupied attachment; withdrawers have dismissive attachment; immediate-fixers manage through action; steady-stayers have earned secure attachment. Recognizing your stress pattern is the first step to changing it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different stress patterns interlock in predictable ways. The anxious-seeker pursues the withdrawer, who retreats more, triggering more pursuit. This dance can be exhausting until you name it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared stress patterns can amplify or balance. Two anxious-seekers may exhaust each other; two withdrawers may never address issues. Awareness helps.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Under relationship stress, what pattern do you fall into? Is this helping or hurting? What would a healthier pattern look like?

questions.text: What helps me regulate my emotions when I'm triggered?

therapeutic.rationale: Emotion regulation needs vary by attachment style. Presence-needers co-regulate through connection; space-needers self-regulate before connecting; talk-through processors need verbal expression; physical-grounders use body to calm mind. Knowing your partner's regulation style helps you support without overwhelming.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different regulation needs can clash. The presence-needer feels abandoned by the space-needer; the space-needer feels overwhelmed by the presence-needer. Ask: 'What do you need right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared regulation needs make support intuitive. You'll naturally offer what helps because it's what you need too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're emotionally triggered, what helps you regulate? What makes it worse? Does your partner know how to help?
